verses.text: Before the Feast of Passover, Jesus knew that His hour had come to depart from this world to the Father. Having loved His own who were in the world, He loved them to the very end.
verses.comment: Jesus' awareness that 'His hour had come' signals the start of His Passion—the sacrifice for humanity's salvation. The emphasis on Jesus' love hints at both His divinity and the depth of covenant faithfulness, which is fulfilled perfectly in Him.

verses.text: During supper, when the devil had already put it into the heart of Judas Iscariot, Simon's son, to betray Him,
verses.comment: Judas’ betrayal fulfills Old Testament prophecy (cf. Ps. 41:9). The mention of the devil's influence highlights the spiritual struggle occurring beneath these historical events.

verses.text: Jesus, knowing that the Father had given all things into His hands, and that He had come from God and was going back to God,
verses.comment: This verse affirms Jesus’ divine origin and authority. 'All things into His hands' speaks to His kingship and priestly role, preparing for the events to come.

verses.text: He rose from supper, laid aside His outer garment, and taking a towel, tied it around Himself.
verses.comment: Jesus' act is a gesture of humility. This foreshadows His self-emptying sacrifice and the model He sets for servant leadership in His Church.

verses.text: Then He poured water into a basin and began to wash the disciples’ feet and to wipe them with the towel wrapped around Him.
verses.comment: Foot washing, a servant's task, demonstrates Christ’s call to humility. Early Church leaders took this as a pattern for true authority based on service.

verses.text: Then He came to Simon Peter, who said to Him, 'Lord, are You going to wash my feet?'
verses.comment: Peter’s reaction reflects awe and a sense of unworthiness before the Lord’s humble service. His response echoes the reverence due to Christ.

verses.text: Jesus answered him, 'What I am doing you do not understand now, but afterward you will understand.'
verses.comment: Here, Jesus foreshadows greater spiritual truths revealed after His resurrection, highlighting the developing understanding among the disciples guided by the Holy Spirit.

verses.text: Peter said to Him, 'You shall never wash my feet.' Jesus answered him, 'If I do not wash you, you have no share with Me.'
verses.comment: Jesus’ words allude spiritually to cleansing beyond mere ritual, foreshadowing baptism and the sacramental life needed for union with Him.

verses.text: Simon Peter said to Him, 'Lord, not my feet only but also my hands and my head!'
verses.comment: Peter's enthusiasm shows deep desire for communion with Christ, even if he doesn’t fully grasp the symbolic meaning at this moment.

verses.text: Jesus said to him, 'One who has bathed does not need to wash except for his feet, but is completely clean. And you are clean, but not all of you.'
verses.comment: Christ hints at the sacrament of cleansing, which sets the faithful apart. Yet He acknowledges exceptions, referencing the presence of a betrayer.

verses.text: For He knew who was to betray Him; that was why He said, 'Not all of you are clean.'
verses.comment: John emphasizes Jesus’ foreknowledge, underlining His divinity. His statement addresses spiritual rather than external purity.

verses.text: When He had washed their feet and put on His garments, He resumed His place and said to them, 'Do you understand what I have done to you?'
verses.comment: Jesus connects the action to the deeper truth—He models the humility and leadership He expects in the Church.

verses.text: 'You call Me Teacher and Lord, and you are right, for so I am.'
verses.comment: Jesus affirms His status as the ultimate teacher and master, which implies authority to command and instruct in faith and morality.

verses.text: If I then, your Lord and Teacher, have washed your feet, you also ought to wash one another's feet.
verses.comment: Christ’s example becomes a command for mutual humility and sacrificial love among believers—revealing the pattern of leadership He desires.

verses.text: For I have given you an example, that you also should do just as I have done to you.
verses.comment: Jesus passes a pattern to be imitated, underlining the ongoing nature of self-giving service in the life of the Church.

verses.text: Truly, truly, I say to you, a servant is not greater than his master, nor is a messenger greater than the one who sent him.
verses.comment: The phrase 'Truly, truly' reinforces the authority and solemnity of Jesus’ instruction, rooting it in the divine order.

verses.text: If you know these things, blessed are you if you do them.
verses.comment: Faithful action is necessary, not just knowledge. Obedience leads to true blessing, according to Jesus’ words.

verses.text: I am not speaking of all of you; I know whom I have chosen. But this Scripture will be fulfilled: 'He who eats My bread has lifted his heel against Me.'
verses.comment: Jesus applies Old Testament prophecy to His betrayal, showing God’s sovereign plan unfolding in history.

verses.text: I am telling you this now, before it takes place, so that when it does take place you may believe that I am He.
verses.comment: Christ’s declaration 'I am He' uses the divine name (ego eimi), showing high Christology: He identifies Himself as God.

verses.text: Truly, truly, I say to you, whoever receives the one I send receives Me, and whoever receives Me receives the One who sent Me.
verses.comment: Jesus equates those sent by Him with Himself, implying a sacramental ministry—those who represent Christ have His authority.

verses.text: After saying these things, Jesus was troubled in His spirit, and testified, 'Truly, truly, I say to you, one of you will betray Me.'
verses.comment: Jesus’ human emotions are shown, highlighting His true humanity as well as His divinity.

verses.text: The disciples looked at one another, uncertain of whom He spoke.
verses.comment: This uncertainty shows the close fellowship among the apostles and the hidden nature of Judas's intentions.

verses.text: One of His disciples, whom Jesus loved, was reclining next to Jesus.
verses.comment: The beloved disciple’s intimacy with Jesus is an example of the deep spiritual relationship available to followers of Christ.

verses.text: So Simon Peter motioned to him to ask Jesus of whom He was speaking.
verses.comment: Peter relies on the beloved disciple’s intimacy to gain special insight—showing the diversity of roles among Christ’s followers.

verses.text: So that disciple, leaning back against Jesus, said to Him, 'Lord, who is it?'
verses.comment: This question demonstrates how boldness can come from closeness to Christ—a pattern for all disciples seeking truth.

verses.text: Jesus answered, 'It is he to whom I will give this morsel of bread when I have dipped it.' So when He had dipped the morsel, He gave it to Judas, the son of Simon Iscariot.
verses.comment: The intimacy of sharing bread points to the seriousness of betrayal, evoking Old Testament shades of covenant faithlessness.

verses.text: Then after he had taken the morsel, Satan entered into him. Jesus said to him, 'What you are going to do, do quickly.'
verses.comment: John reveals that Judas’s betrayal is more than human failing: it is diabolical participation. Jesus maintains sovereign control of the unfolding plan.

verses.text: Now no one at the table knew why He had said this to him.
verses.comment: The disciples’ confusion suggests that Christ’s plan and the mysteries of salvation are often veiled to us until the right time.

verses.text: Some thought that, because Judas had the money bag, Jesus was telling him, 'Buy what we need for the feast,' or that he should give something to the poor.
verses.comment: Judas's role as treasurer reflects the practical organization among the disciples, grounding the story in historical reality.

verses.text: So, after receiving the morsel of bread, he immediately went out. And it was night.
verses.comment: 'It was night' suggests more than a time of day; symbolically, it denotes spiritual darkness entering with Judas's actions.

verses.text: When he had gone out, Jesus said, 'Now is the Son of Man glorified, and God is glorified in Him.'
verses.comment: Christ’s passion will be His moment of glory, as predicted in prophecy, revealing His identity as the divine Son of Man.

verses.text: If God is glorified in Him, God will also glorify Him in Himself, and will glorify Him at once.
verses.comment: The unity between Father and Son is revealed in mutual glorification—showing the divinity of Christ and the mystery of the Trinity.

verses.text: 'Little children, I am with you a little while longer. You will seek Me; and just as I said to the Jews, so now I also say to you, ‘Where I am going, you cannot come.’'
verses.comment: 'Little children' expresses pastoral care and spiritual fatherhood, emphasizing Jesus’ family-like leadership over the Church.

verses.text: A new commandment I give to you, that you love one another: just as I have loved you, you also are to love one another.
verses.comment: The ‘new commandment’ draws believers into Christ’s own love, the foundation for true Christian unity as seen in the apostolic Church’s structure.

verses.text: By this all people will know that you are My disciples, if you have love for one another.
verses.comment: Love becomes the mark of Christ’s followers, through which the world will recognize the true Church.

verses.text: Simon Peter said to Him, 'Lord, where are you going?' Jesus answered him, 'Where I am going, you cannot follow Me now, but you will follow afterward.'
verses.comment: Jesus predicts Peter’s eventual martyrdom, showing his leadership role and final imitation of Christ’s sacrifice.

verses.text: Peter said to Him, 'Lord, why can I not follow You now? I will lay down my life for You.'
verses.comment: Peter’s zeal exceeds his understanding. His later restoration by Christ will show leadership based on grace, not human effort alone.

verses.text: Jesus answered, 'Will you lay down your life for Me? Truly, truly, I say to you, the rooster will not crow until you have denied Me three times.'
verses.comment: Jesus’ prophecy of Peter’s denial displays His divine knowledge and reinforces the need for forgiveness and restoration, key elements in the faith handed down from the apostles.
